rememberedPersonSummary.name: Maureen Crowe
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. 

Our amazing and brave Mam passed away on February 18th. In the fortnight leading up to her passing, the Macmillan carers and district nurses provided Mam with a level of care and comfort that blew us all away. In the hardest days of all of our lives, the support that they provided us all with was simply amazing. This allowed Mam to be comfortable at home in her final days - exactly as she wanted. 

The nurses and Macmillan carers truly were a light in the darkness for all of us. You never think that this will happen to you or to members of your family but when it does, you truly appreciate the vocation that these professionals are carrying out every single day. 

We fully appreciate that times are hard for people at the moment but if you do feel that you are able to donate anything at all, we would love to give something back to them.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thank you for your support with my month-long DECHOX! My page donations will be sent direct to the British Heart Foundation in a fast and secure way. Your support will help beat heartbreak from the world's biggest killers. Conditions like heart diseases, stroke and vascular dementia. Your support funds research that helps to keep families together.

It’s #NationalHeart Month ❤ and to help raise awareness I'm doing a DETOX challenge....... I'm going to give up chocolate.......Yes you read it right, 1 whole month, 31 days - that's 44,640 minutes.

May sound easy but it's not just about not eating chocolate it means no COCOA so any foods that contain traces of chocolate, cocoa powder is off limits and doing a triple whammy by also giving up fizzy drinks and all types of sweets.

Why am I doing this - Heart Disease is one of UK's biggest killers, did you know on average today in the UK;

  • 460 people will die from a heart or circulatory disease.....
  • More than 120 of those people will be under the age of 75.....
  • There are 7.4 million people living with a heart or circulatory disease
  • There are 280 hospital admissions on a daily basis which are attributed to a heart attack
  • 180 people will die from coronary heart disease.....
  • Heart defects are diagnosed in at least 1 in 150 births – that's an average of 13 babies each day in the UK

I want to help and do my bit by raising money via donations for the British Heart Foundation to further support and aid the research into heart disease.

story:

So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. story:
Conrad & Shirley both tragically passed away within a few days of one another from covid. 

The British Heart Foundation was a cause close to Conrad and Shirley's heart.  Their son Alyn passed away from a heart attack and Shirley had heart problems herself.  

If you prefer to send a cheque, E C Thomas are also collecting donations in their memory.  They are collecting for different causes, Marie Curie & Mcmillan. 

They were loved by so many and will be dearly missed by all.

story:
Anyone that knows me knows I’m the worlds biggest chocoholic. 🍫 So I thought I’d need an incentive to motivate me through March without any form of chocolate. 💪🏻What better way than to contribute to a charity that helps so many. 

💔Heart problems do not discriminate. They effect babies, the young, middle aged and the old in equal proportions, from congenital heart disease to vascular dementia. My first job in the NHS was a HCA on a cardiac/medical ward. Every week the British Heart Foundation visited to speak to those who needed support with their heart conditions. Some patients depended highly on those visits which gave them the tools to rehabilitate and change their lifestyle to manage their specific problem❤️. Like any other charity this year has had a big impact and they need our help. 🦠 

I promise I won’t touch any form of chocolate for the whole of March if you could help me and donate as much or as little as you can to reach my target. As well as helping out a girls waistline 😑😉 you’ll be contributing to such a worthy cause x thank you x

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Terry Wesley
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
I've been looking for a challenge as I've felt myself really struggling through February after my January challenges ended. Funnily enough I actually turnt to my crutch, food-chocolate, sweets and fizzy! 

 This challenge came about because a good friend of mine, Amber, has set up a support group where she teaches fitcamps, well-being and nutritional support. Amber decided she didn't want to be paid for it. She wanted us to support her friend Ellie who's doing this challenge to raise money.This charity is very close to her heart and I've chosen to join.


The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. story:
Anyone that knows me will know how much I love chocolate! ❤️ 🍫 

So this challenge will pretty hard for me but I will do it and resist the temptation and in the process raise money for charity and lose some weight at the same time, win win! 

Having children means there will always be snacks in the cupboard but for every pound I loose in weight will mean I’m learning to make better choices and in the long run being there longer for them as unfortunately you just don’t know what’s around the corner but prevention is the key 🔑.

My Gran suffered a heart attack when I was around 10 and luckily at the time it was just a small one but she then suffered with Angina and so I watched her having to take medication daily while controlling her food because unfortunately she also had a high cholesterol too. She wasn’t a big lady either so it doesn’t matter what size you are, you still have to look after yourself.

If you can donate a £1 (average price for a bar/bag of chocolate) then I’d really appreciate it, it all adds up ☺️

rememberedPersonSummary.name: William Reynolds
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support.

I started running in September 2020 to get me out of the house whilst working from home. I am pleased that I have kept this up but now I want to push myself and so I am challenging myself to run a total of 83km throughout March. Why 83km? I sadly lost my Grandad in 2017 and he was 83 when he died. I am completing this challenge in memory of him, so I am running a km for every year of his life.

 The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Jim Hagans
story:
As many of you know, Jim suffered with heart problems for many years, but he never let this stop him from living life to the full. From going on many holidays, spending time with his family (especially his beloved grandchildren) and socialising with friends, Jim had time for everyone and would do anything he could to help and support those around him. This support extended to the British Heart Foundation, a charity Jim enjoyed supporting by spending his hard earned money in their charity shops on books, toys for the grandchildren and clothes. His most recent and proudest purchase was a smart gentleman’s overcoat which kept him lovely and warm as we dragged him round all the local parks with the grandkids!!

Jim wouldn’t have appreciated flowers, so if you would like to make a charity donation in exchange for floral tributes, we would be extremely grateful.

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Hi everyone...thank you all for taking the time to read my story.

4 years ago this August my family was hit with the tragic news that my grandad had passed away suddenly of a heart attack. 

4 years on...it doesnt get any easier.....I miss him and my nan everyday...I would do anything to be able to give them 1 more hug and to tell them i love them.

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation. Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss. We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
A couple of weeks ago, my mum mentioned potentially doing this challenge, in light of my 24hr run in November, with Jake Sanders. This challenge was invented by David Goggins. Goggins is an ex-Navy Seal and the only seal in history to do hell week 3 times. He does this every year as to raise awareness of one's mental and physical capabilities. His aim is to show us what we are capable of, if we put our minds to it. I was inspired by his message and thought, as I am stuck in lockdown, why not push myself to see how far I can physically and mentally go. 

The challenge entails running 4 miles (6.4km) every 4 hours for 48 hours. That's a cumulative mileage of 76km in 48hrs. Now, as somewhat of a mediocre runner myself, I thought this looked very hard but something worth attempting. I am training for just under 3 weeks for this and planning on starting at 12:00pm the 6th March and finishing at 8:00am on the 8th March. After a lot of research, I have concluded that the sleep deprivation combined with the serious muscle fatigue will really test me; but I am willing to accept the challenge.

I will attempt to do as much as I can unless injury or incapability prevents me. I want to prove to myself that we can do more than we think we are capable of and our minds can push us through severe discomfort in life.

I would greatly appreciate any donations, to a great charity and a charity that saved my eyesight when I was very young. I would not be able to do many things today, without the amazing cataract surgery I received. 

I sincerely hope I can finish this challenge and make both myself and the charity proud.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.



I’m raising money for Great Ormand St Hospital.
My nephew Beau is currently receiving treatment for a rare Congenital Heart Defect called Ebsteins Anomaly.
Ebsteins Anomaly is defined by a deformed Tricuspid Valve which affects around 1 in 200k live births and represents just 1% of all CHD’s.
He was diagnosed at birth and so far has been coping well however he needs to undergo open heart surgery this year at GOSH to repair his valve and improve his quality of life. 

CHECK OUT THE PICTURE GALLERY.

My work will match what we raise too!

GOSH is one of the leading children’s hospitals in the world specialising in children’s cancers, neurosurgery, paediatric intensive care and cardiac surgery.
Their mission is to help the sickest children with complex health needs to fulfil their potential.

CHD’s are just one of the life threatening diseases that there is still much unknown about what causes them and how to treat them.

story:
JOE ROWS THE TYNE FOR CANCER RESEARCH UK

Breast cancer is the most commonly occurring cancer in women and the second most common cancer overall. 

Until the beginning of this year, I hadn’t had any experience of cancer first hand. So when my Mum was diagnosed with breast cancer last year, it was quite honestly one of the most horrendous feelings I’ve ever had. Worry and uncertainty flooded over me as I realised there was nothing I could do to help. 

My Mum has always been the matriarch of our family: strong, sassy and outspoken and in the instance of breast cancer, she stayed true to form! Determined not to be beaten, my Mum remained hopeful throughout her diagnosis, keeping the rest of the family in positive spirits from hundreds of miles away in Spain. 

Thanks to an early diagnosis, they were able to remove  the cancerous lump and with the success of radiotherapy, my Mum is set to make a full recovery. I appreciate not all families are this lucky. 

So in an attempt to use my complete lack of a job to do some good, I will be using the month of March to raise money for Cancer Research UK, rowing the distance of the River Tyne on a rowing machine. As an extra little incentive to gain your support, I will also cut off my (very long) hair and donate it to Little Princess Trust to use to make a wig for a child who has lost their own hair through cancer treatment.

Please be a part of my mission to do some good by supporting Cancer Research UK. 

Donate now

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Madhukar  Gulhane
story:
In memory of our loving Baba/Ajoba, Madhukar Gulhane, who leaves behind his wife Asha, sons Vishal and Nilesh and a grandson Aayush.

For those of you who didnt know Baba well, he was a perfect thorough soft spoken gentleman whose actions spoke more than words. He was a man of few words but his life is a message and inspiration to us all.

Spiritually inclined, well read and a man of many interests he never left any stone unturned where experience is concerned and hence he could converse intelligently about anything may it be spirituality, politics, diy, food, travel, ayurveda and yes gadgets too. He was always a keen learner and would be happy with any new gadget. He had a childlike nature. He lived a full life and has moved on but will continue to live in our hearts forever.

In brief span of last 10 months since covid lockdown in 2020 Baba battled cancer and during this time we have been truly humbled by the cancer care that we have recieved from the NHS and the palliative care team at St Lukes and Marie Curie who looked after Baba in last days of his life,  hence we would be grateful if you could donate to this charity of our choice who do a selfless job of caring for terminally ill people in their own homes. 

Thankyou for  your donation and supporting the cause.

story:
We're the RNLI Portishead lifeboat station. We operate the 8.5 metre Atlantic 85 class lifeboat 'My Lady Anne' on the Bristol Channel and the River Avon. And our volunteer crew is ready to launch at any time of day or night to save lives at sea.

It's been a tough year for all of us. But we've remained operational throughout the pandemic. And we're expecting another busy year ahead. Our fundraising has taken a big hit, though. And we need your support now more than ever before.

We can't get out and about like we usually would. And so we're doing jigsaws. For every pound donated via this page, we'll add another piece to the puzzle. And we'll post a photo each day to show you how we're getting on.

We're starting with a small puzzle. It's got 38 pieces. And we'll see how we get on. So please do support us if you can. We know it's an awful idea. But we're locked down, just like you, and it's the best we can come up with :)

Oh, and if the first few small puzzles go well, we've got a stonking great 1,000 piece one in reserve. And we're not afraid to use it.

All money donated will go towards helping children in high-risk countries such as Yemen. Over 12 million children were already at risk in Yemen and now the coronas virus pandemic continues to put them in danger, with 80% of Yemen’s population in need of humanitarian aid and protection. 

More than five years of fighting has pushed Yemen and its health system to the brink of collapse. Millions of children lack access to clean water and sanitation facilities and are in desperate need of basic healthcare. Malnutrition is also at an all-time high. 2 million children are acutely malnourished and over 368,000 children under 5 are suffering from severe malnutrition and urgently need life-saving food to survive. Just £11 could provide life-saving food for a child for a week. Thank you for taking the time to read and thanks for all your support.

story:
I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.
Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.
The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.
Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
From Manchester to Madagascar 

From 15th February, well be walking, running, cycling, rowing and swimming to travel the 5,777 miles between Manchester to Madagascar, all in aid of highlighting WaterAid's work in Antenanarivo, Madagascar.

5,777 miles might take us a while to complete, so we are going to compete in two teams and start at each end - one team in Manchester and one team in Madagascar - and the objective is to meet in the middle by Easter, and see who gets there first!

Well be walking, running, cycling, rowing or even swimming (when allowed!) to help contribute individually and virtually to the 5,777 miles we need to complete together. 

The objective is to improve all our wellbeing, get us all out more in the fresh air and away from our computers, and to raise £5,777 for a truly magnificent cause!

story:
Our eldest daughter was inspired to take action after watching a video about a little girl in Africa who struggled to access to clean water.  She suggested we all commit to a family bike ride. As a family of 4 we are cycling a total of 400 miles together throughout the month of March to raise funds for WaterAid for children and families who need access to water.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.
